description:
UMD 3.9.0 is the ninth update of the third Major release of UMD 
(Unified Middleware Distribution) made available for the EGI production 
infrastructure. This release contains support for both Scientific Linux 5
 and 6 and also Debian 6 (Squeeze).
releaseNotes:
This release contains the following products:<br><br>Accounting<br><ul><li><b>APEL, v. 1.2.2</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This update fixes the issue of the client being unable to parse uncompressed accounting logs.</li></ul></ul>Authorization<br><ul><li><b>DPM-argus plugin, v. 1.8.8</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This release provides a little packaging fix to <strong>dpm-argus</strong> to make it work 
across EPEL and EMI, through different release numbers. dpm-argus now 
will work with any dpm-mysql-nameserver whose version is greater than 
1.8.7.</li><li> The fix also adds to the dpm-argus package the 
dpns-arguspoll manpage, which was left behind by mistake in the recent 
release of this component.</li></ul></ul>Client Tools<br><ul><li><b>dCache srmclient 2.2.27</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This release fixes the export SRM_PATH bug in srmrmdir and the ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when processing multiple surls invoking srmget.</li></ul></ul><ul><li><b>EMI UI, v. 3.1.0</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This is a repacking release just to add the new dependencies on gfal2-util &amp; ginfo.<br></li></ul></ul><ul><li><b>GFAL2-util, v. 1.0.0</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>First
 release in UMD of the GFAL 2 util which is a group of command line 
tools for file manipulations with any protocol managed by gfal 2.0<br></li></ul></ul><ul><li><b>SRM-ifce, v. 1.20.0</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>Minor
 release in order to solve some bug fix like the excessive cpu usage 
from srm-ifce function or the Initialize time fields when 
stating/listing.</li></ul></ul>Credential management<br><ul><li><b>MyProxy, v. 5.9.8-2</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>First
 release in UMD-3 of the popular MyProxy from Globus which allows to 
manage&nbsp; X.509 Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) security credentials 
(certificates and private keys).</li></ul></ul>Data Acces<br><ul><li><b>DAVIX, v. 0.3.6</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This is a bug fix release which solves, among others, the OpenSSL issue with davix cmd line tools and password shell.</li></ul></ul>Information Discovery, Information Model<br><ul><li><b>BDII-core, v. 1.6.1</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This is a minor release containing a set of new features and minor fixes to the 
following packages: bdii, glue-validator, glue-schema and 
glite-info-provider-service.
		</li></ul></ul><ul><li><b>QCG Broker EGI IS provider, v. 3.4.0</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>Initial version of Information Provider for GLUE 1.3 and GLUE 2.0<br></li></ul></ul>File Access<br><ul><li><b>CVMFS, v. 2.1.19</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This
 is the first release in UMD of the client of the CernVM File System 
which is a network file system based on HTTP and optimized to deliver 
experiment software in a fast, scalable, and reliable way.<br></li></ul></ul>File Access, File Transfer, Storage Management<br><ul><li><b>dCache server, v. 2.6.35</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This release provides:</li><ul><li>fixes
 affecting multiple services: - The nfs and srm both cache replies from 
gPlazma to increase the speed of authenticating and identifying the 
user. Previously transient errors when communicating with gPlazma were 
also cached, delaying the recovery time from such errors. Now, such 
errors are not cached.</li><li>NFS - No longer trigger an NullPointerException when opening the .(parent)() dot-command file in Chimera's root directory.</li><li>POOL
 - Fix xrootd support for vector read. The problem was discovered with 
ROOT v6, which reports errors like Single readv transfer is too large.</li></ul><ul><li>XROOTD
 - Fix problems when calculating a response to the kXR_set request. If 
encountered, the problem results in the following being logged, where 
nnn in xrootd-disk-nnn is some integer number: 'Uncaught exception in 
thread xrootd-disk-nnn java.lang.IllegalStateException: null'</li></ul></ul></ul>Job Execution, Job Scheduling<br><ul><li><b>ARC, v. 13.11.2</b>, versions for SL5, SL6 and Debian</li><ul><li>This update contains changes to the following component versions.</li><ul><li>Nordugrid ARC to 4.2.0</li><li>Nordugrid ARC doc to 1.5.0</li><li>Nagios probes for ARC CE to 1.8.1</li></ul><li>There have been several bugfixes and updates with this version, more details in the release notes:<br><div><div>
<a href="http://www.nordugrid.org/arc/releases/13.11u2/release_notes_13.11u2.html">http://www.nordugrid.org/arc/releases/13.11u2/release_notes_13.11u2.html</a></div></div></li></ul></ul><ul><li><b>CREAM SLURM module,v. 1.0.2</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This release provides a bug fix in the info-dynamic-scheduler-slurm namely SLURM provider should publish undefined values and missing check in triggerun<br></li></ul></ul><ul><li><b>CREAM LSF module</b>,&nbsp; v. 2.0.4, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This release provides multiple bugfix afecting the info-dynamic-scheduler and also an improved Glue2 support<br></li></ul></ul><ul><li><b>EMI WN, v. 3.1.0</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This is a repacking release just to add the new dependencies on gfal2-util &amp; ginfo.<br></li></ul></ul><ul><li><b>QCG Compute, v. 2.4.0</b>, versions for SL5:</li><ul><li>This is a minor release which introduce some bug fix and Updated the Java SDK to use JGlobus 2.0.8 it also introduces a new package for application scripts.<br></li></ul></ul>Job Scheduling<br><ul><li><b>QCG Broker, v. 3.4.0</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This
 release provides a new release for both the broker and the client and 
among several bugfix it provides support for parameter sweep jobs, new 
resource filters and improvements in data transfers.<br></li></ul></ul><ul><li><b>WMS, v. 3.6.6</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This
 is a bug fix release which provides a fix for the case were the WMProxy
 deletes a user delegated proxy on list-match operation and for the case
 were a CE can cause WMS to become very slow dealing with all other 
jobs. This release also contains a new version of the WMS UI which 
solves the issue of setting umask 0077 leading ot the issue that the 
sandbox was not writable by the WMS.</li></ul></ul>Messaging<br><ul><li><b>QCG Notifier, v. 3.4.0</b>, versions for SL5:</li><ul><li>This is a minor which introduce some bug fixes and also Disable the KEEP_ALIVE flag for the anonymous and SSL publishers.</li></ul></ul>Parallel Job:<br><ul><li><b>MPI, v. 1.5.3</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This is an update release of mpi-start 1.x series that fixes the following issue:<a href="https://github.com/IFCA/mpi-start/issues/12"> #12</a> - Wrong order in the list of hosts</li></ul></ul><br>Other<br><ul><li><b>caNl, v. 2.2.4</b>, versions for SL5, SL6 and Debian, containing:<br></li><ul><li><b>canl-c, v. 2.1.5:</b></li><ul><li id="aui_3_2_0_1199"> This revision fixes long-discussed certificate chain validation errors.</li></ul></ul><ul><li><b>canl-java, v. 1.3.3</b>:</li><ul><li>This update solves two closely related bugfixes of OCSP handling:
		</li><ul><li> failing OCSP responders are now cached (up to now only responses were cached)</li><li> the memory consumed by the in-memory cache of OCSP is now limited (was unconstrained).</li></ul></ul></ul></ul><ul><li><b>CGSI-gSOAP, v. 1.3.6</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This update fixes:</li><ul><li><a href="https://its.cern.ch/jira/issues/LCGUTIL-55">[LCGUTIL-55]</a> - API to set/get at runtime the different possible credentials</li><li><a href="https://its.cern.ch/jira/issues/LCGUTIL-384">[LCGUTIL-384]</a> - Remove compilation warnings on cgsi-gsoap</li><li><a href="https://its.cern.ch/jira/issues/LCGUTIL-430">[LCGUTIL-430]</a>&nbsp;- Disable weak ciphers</li></ul></ul></ul><ul><li><b>GFAL2, v. 2.6.8</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This release presents several new functionalities and improvements among several bug fixes. Now Gfal2&nbsp; provides xrootd and http supports as well as support for dCache.<br></li></ul></ul><ul><li><b>GFAL2-python, v. 1.5.0,</b> versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>Minor release which adds a buffer size parameter to the gfal-cp command and solves the issue of the Python bindings do not expose create parent option for copies.<br></li></ul></ul><ul><li><b>gfalFS, v. 1.5.0</b>, versions for SL5 and SL6:</li><ul><li>This is a minor release which introduces a bug fix for the du command in mounted file system reporting&nbsp; 0 for each file.<br></li></ul></ul>
installationNotes:
All products in the UMD 3.9.0 release were verified against EGI's 
current  Quality Criteria (for further information, please see the 
documentation links) to support 64 bit Scientific Linux 5 and Scientific
 Linux 6 (x86_64 processor architecture). Some products are also 
supported in 64 bit Debian 6 (squeeze).  Installation and configuration 
notes are available in the <a href="http://repository.egi.eu/category/umd_releases/distribution/umd-3/"><a>EGI repository</a>.<br></a>
contact:
For further information about the UMD, its goals and surrounding processes, and
more information about how to engage as a Technology Provider with EGI, please
send an Email to: cto (at) egi.eu.
technicalContact: For any bugs and issues you encounter that are not described in the release <br>notes of this UMD release, or the related documentation provided by the <br>Technology Providers, please visit the <a href="https://ggus.eu/">EGI Helpdesk</a> to make a report.
knownIssues: Details containing known issues and workarounds found in EGI verification and&nbsp; staged rollout are collected in:<br><a href="https://wiki.egi.eu/wiki/UMD-3:UMD-3.9.0">https://wiki.egi.eu/wiki/UMD-3:UMD-3.9.0</a>
changeLog: This releases includes updates for the following products: APEL, ARC, caNl, BDII-core, CGSI-gSOAP, CREAM LSF module, CREAM SLURM module, CVMFS, DAVIX, dCache server, DPM-argus, EMI UI, EMI WN, GFAL2, GFAL2-util, GFAL2-python, gfalFS, MPI, MyProxy, QCG Broker, QCG Broker EGI IS Provider, QCG Compute, QCG Notifier, SRM-ifce, WMS

products.name: arc.arc
products.description: The Advanced Resource Connector (ARC) middleware is an Open Source software solution to enable distributed computing infrastructures with the emphasis on processing large volumes of data. ARC provides an abstraction layer over computational resources, complete with input and output data movement functionalities. The security model of ARC is identical to that of Grid solutions, relying on delegation of user credentials and the concept of Virtual Organisations. ARC also provides client tools, as well as API in C++, Python and Java

products.name: cernvm.cvmfs
products.description: CernVM File System (CernVM-FS) is a network file system based on HTTP and optimized to deliver experiment software in a fast, scalable, and reliable way. Files and file metadata are aggressively cached and downloaded on demand. Thereby the CernVM-FS decouples the life cycle management of the application software releases from the operating system. CernVM-FS is included in CernVM, however it can also be used outside CernVM.

products.name: dcache.dcache-srmclient
products.description: The SRM Client 2.2.22 follows the FHS compliant directory layout.

products.name: dcache.dcache
products.description: dCache provides system for storing and retrieving huge amounts of data, distributed among a large number of heterogenous server nodes, under a single virtual filesystem tree with a variety of standard access methods.

products.name: emi.apel
products.description: APEL (Accounting Processor for Event Logs) is a tool that gathers CPU accounting information by parsing batch system and blah accounting log files and inserts it into a local MySQL database. APEL then publishes the data into a centralised repository.

products.name: emi.bdii-core
products.description: Grid information systems are mission-critical components in today's production grid infrastructures. They provide detailed information about grid services which is needed for various different tasks. The EMI information system has a hierarchical structure of three levels. The fundamental building block used in this hierarchy is the Berkley Database Information Index (BDII). Although the BDII has additional complexity, it can be visualized as an LDAP database. The resource level BDII is usually co-located with the grid service and provides information about that service. Each grid site runs a site level BDII. This aggregates the information from all the resource level BDIIs running at that site. The top level BDII aggregates all the information from all the site level BDIIs and hence contains information about all grid services. There are multiple instances of the top level BDII in order to provide a fault tolerant, load balanced service. The information system clients query a top level BDII to find the information that they require.

products.name: emi.bdii-core
products.description: Grid information systems are mission-critical components in today's production grid infrastructures. They provide detailed information about grid services which is needed for various different tasks. The EMI information system has a hierarchical structure of three levels. The fundamental building block used in this hierarchy is the Berkley Database Information Index (BDII). Although the BDII has additional complexity, it can be visualized as an LDAP database. The resource level BDII is usually co-located with the grid service and provides information about that service. Each grid site runs a site level BDII. This aggregates the information from all the resource level BDIIs running at that site. The top level BDII aggregates all the information from all the site level BDIIs and hence contains information about all grid services. There are multiple instances of the top level BDII in order to provide a fault tolerant, load balanced service. The information system clients query a top level BDII to find the information that they require.
products.releaseNotes: new version of glue-validator which applies an internal workaround for not testing the Admin Foreign Key attributes in the case of StoRM services as there is a known bug in the information provider that prevents from publishing correct information.
products.changeLog: new version of glue-validator which applies an internal workaround for not testing the Admin Foreign Key attributes in the case of StoRM services as there is a known bug in the information provider that prevents from publishing correct information.

products.name: emi.canl
products.description: http://unicore-dev.zam.kfa-juelich.de/documentation/canl-1.1.0/manual.html
products.changeLog: This revision fixes long-discussed certificate chain validation errors. This update contains a single fix for a regression/bug introduced in the 1.3.1 release: issue-65 which is relevant for proxy certificate users.

products.name: emi.canl
products.description: http://unicore-dev.zam.kfa-juelich.de/documentation/canl-1.1.0/manual.html
products.changeLog: This revision fixes long-discussed certificate chain validation errors. This update contains a single fix for a regression/bug introduced in the 1.3.1 release: issue-65 which is relevant for proxy certificate users.

products.name: emi.cream-lsf
products.description:
The CREAM (Computing Resource Execution And Management) Service is a simple, lightweight service for job management operation at the Computing Element (CE) level.



CREAM accepts job submission requests (which are described with the same JDL language used to describe the jobs submitted to the Workload Management System) and other job management requests (e.g. job cancellation, job monitoring, etc).



CREAM can be used by the Workload Management System (WMS), via the ICE service, or by a generic client, e.g. an end-user willing to directly submit jobs to a CREAM CE. For the latter user case a command line interface (CLI) is available.

products.name: emi.cream-slurm
products.description:
The CREAM (Computing Resource Execution And Management) Service is a simple, lightweight service for job management operation at the Computing Element (CE) level.



CREAM accepts job submission requests (which are described with the same JDL language used to describe the jobs submitted to the Workload Management System) and other job management requests (e.g. job cancellation, job monitoring, etc).



CREAM can be used by the Workload Management System (WMS), via the ICE service, or by a generic client, e.g. an end-user willing to directly submit jobs to a CREAM CE. For the latter user case a command line interface (CLI) is available.

products.name: emi.dpm-argus
products.description:
The Disk Pool Manager (DPM) is a lightweight storage solution for grid sites. It offers a

simple way to create a disk-based grid storage element and supports relevant protocols

(SRM, gridFTP, RFIO) for file management and access. It focus on manageability (ease

of installation, configuration, low effort of maintenance), while providing all required

functionality for a grid storage solution (support for multiple disk server nodes,

different space types, multiple file replicas in disk pools).

products.name: epel.myproxy
products.description: MyProxy is open source software for managing X.509 Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) security credentials (certificates and private keys). MyProxy combines an online credential repository with an online certificate authority to allow users to securely obtain credentials when and where needed. Users run myproxy logon to authenticate and obtain credentials, including trusted CA certificates and Certificate Revocation Lists (CRLs).

products.description: https://svnweb.cern.ch/trac/lcgutil/wiki/gfal2

products.name: gfal2.gfal2
products.description: GFAL (Grid File Access Library ) is a C library providing an abstraction layer of the grid storage system complexity.

products.name: qcg.qcg-broker-egi-is-provider
products.description:
QCG-Broker is a successor of the Grid Resource Management System (GRMS)
project. QCG-Broker was designed to be an open-source meta-scheduling
framework that allows developers to build and easily deploy resource
management systems to control large-scale distributed computing
infrastructures running queuing or batch systems locally.
products.changeLog: Initial version of Information Provider for GLUE 1.3 and GLUE 2.0 (based on the emi-resource-information-service package).

products.name: qcg.qcg-broker
products.description:
QCG-Broker is a successor of the Grid Resource Management System (GRMS)
project. QCG-Broker was designed to be an open-source meta-scheduling
framework that allows developers to build and easily deploy resource
management systems to control large-scale distributed computing
infrastructures running queuing or batch systems locally.
products.changeLog:
QCG-broker:
  support for parameter sweep jobs
  changes in handling data transfers
  improvements in brokering algorithms: new resource filters
  integration with BDII information system (qcg-broker-egi-is-provider package).
  bug fixes 
QCG-broker-client:
  support for parameter sweep jobs (#QCG parameter-sweep directive)
  changes in #QCG assistant, monitor, watch-output directives (integration with QCG-Monitoring service)
  new #QCG mount directive (integration with VeilFS system - PLGrid only)
  new qcg-version command displaying version of the qcg package
  bug fixes

products.name: qcg.qcg-comp
products.description: QCG-Computing (formerly known as Smoa Computing) is an open architecture implementation of SOAP Web service for multi-user access and policy-based job control routines by various queuing and batch systems managing local computational resources

products.name: qcg.qcg-ntf
products.description: QCG-Notification is an open source implementation of the family of WS-Notification standards (Base Notification, Brokered Notification and Topics).
